reviews.review_msg: Toby is a great professor. The instructions for the assignments are always explained very clearly and he is genuinely interested in what he is teaching. He provides lots of practice for his midterms and the final. The tests are fair and are a reflection of what is taught in class. I would definitely recommend taking a course with Toby.

He makes learning python for beginners super easy, beginner python is very dry overall but he is a generous marker and cares that you actually pass the class. He also gives a very important outline of what's on the final exam so make sure you do the practice exams. Take it with him!

Attended a couple lectures and couldn't even hear him so I just stopped going. The lectures notes online however are helpful and enough to get by. Just do the weekly quizzes, and then study for midterm and final by doing the samples which are very similar. Did about 1-2 hrs of work a week and still managed to get a decent grade

If you already know Python and basic computing this should be pretty light if not it will definitely take some work. The lectures are a bit dry but the assignments and quiz's are fair and good grade boosts if you don't perform on the exams which aren't super hard anyway.

Toby is a good prof. Lectures are simple and easy to follow, assignments are very helpful, and exams are generally fair. Be careful with those exams though - I underestimated the midterm and completely bombed it. It wasn't difficult by any means, just requires a but of effort.

He was kind of incompetent... He's a CMPT professor but can't set up a microphone. I sat in the 4th row and couldn't hear him at all. I stopped going to the lectures halfway through the semester and just studied and did the work myself.

Pretty mid prof. For context, I already knew python coming into this, the way he teaches python is god awful. He spent way too much time on turtle and txt files instead of more useful things with python like pandas and stats usages. On the final exam, there was a question on something he literally did not cover which definitely f'ed ppl over.

It takes months for him to return marks on quizzes. Each quiz is 10 questions, multiple choice, and online, it should not take months. The midterm was mostly multiple choice and it still took several weeks.

Got a decent grade without much effort because all the quizzes were online , assignments were easy and mid term was basically the last semester mid term with values changed . There is just one problem with the course which is a mcq based final exam , you can loose a lot of marks there . Other than that chill prof and class

Meh, dry lecturer. If you watch lecture recordings + do practice Q's on his obsidian, you'll be fine. Assignments, midterms, and quizzes were fair, but final was a bit hard. Make sure to know ur MC, as half (or maybe more) of our final was MC.

Lectures always feel productive albeit a bit dry + they're recorded. His notes are great for studying. Assignment criteria is clear and they're graded fairly imo. No surprises during exams if you listen to lectures, do the weekly quizzes and hw. Lots of multiple choice; make sure you have a good understanding of underlying concepts/terms.
Substituted for amir, was really kind and got our emails replied to

Absolutely loved him. Fair grading, excellent at explaining. He tries to be funny but he sometimes starts giggling instead LOL. I literally watched all of the lectures starting from week 3 onwards online instead of attending the lectures and I wish I did that from the first week. He is very clear at what he is teaching. TAs and assignments were OK

Toby's lectures were pretty clear, he explains things simply and straightforwardly. He also posted video recordings of the lectures which was really nice. The midterm was insanely easy, the final was tough. Make sure you can do multiple choice. Exams reflect what was taught in class, assignments were fine. Overall solid prof.

exams are pretty easy especially if you pay attention to what he says in class and know the quiz questions. also he is good at explaining concepts and mostly clear about expectations. only complaint is he's kinda weird about answering questions in class/office hours
Toby is the GOAT, amazing lectures, practical teaching, he explains very well, exams were fair, he made the course easy
Boring explanations, unfair horrible multiple choice questions on quizes and exams, very mid.
Strong english, passionate about what he is teaching, goes over crucial important material, does not waste time

Assignments are easy and posted 2 weeks before due date but are riddled with mistakes to the point that you're better off waiting a week before starting them. Exams may contain ambiguous questions. Lectures are okay, but I found myself using John Edgar's lectures over Toby's by the second month.

(Fall 2023) 

I think Toby was a pretty decent prof! I *did* go into this class with some existing experience with Python, but I found that his lectures were very straightforward and his personal website with lecture notes was very well organized. He explained things well and emphasized what would be testable. Pretty funny, too!

Comprehensive notes, recorded lectures, practical teaching. Average workload with 5 assignments throughout the term, weekly quizzes, 1 midterm and 1 final exam. Some issues with grading assignments but I had a positive experience overall.

I genuinely enjoyed toby's class, I am not going to lie we all pretty well initially thought that he wasn't going to be that good but her surprised us all, his lectures were decent but outside of lectures he was incredibly supportive and he provided more than enough materials for all of use to succeed which I genuinely appreciate. GO TOBY :)

Lectures are pretty dry, but technically the teaching style is effective. (Never reads from a slide deck, instead presents a problem related to the topic and solves it in real-time). Occasionally says something funny. Provided resources are really good, (recorded lectures and in-depth notes for each one.) Midterm easier than weekly quizzes.

Easy but fun. Toby gives an average of B+ though according to the average stats in canvas it should be B. Anyway the marking is generous. The only killer is the final (59%) but you can do well by simply memorzing all the stuff.
Learned a lot about functional programming in this course, and the prof definitely knew what he was talking about.

Where do I begin? Completely disorganized lectures, awkward when answering questions, and marking seems to be utter madness at best. Just to give you an idea of how insane the grading scheme was, participation was worth more than the final exam. Also, if you so much as get the capitalization wrong for your function name, the whole thing is wrong.

The class is not difficult, but the concepts learned are very engaging. To add to this, Toby has done everyone a favour by uploading a lecture recording of every class. This makes it so that you can simply stay at home, and watch the lectures videos 1.5x speed. Toby also explains concepts well. I would recommend this class to everyone in CMPT/SoSy.

Toby is an experienced profs. Pay attention to lecture and read course notes ahead. It is not easy to get a good grade if you dont spend lots of time on this course (Unless you're super familiar with C++) You may find that assignment instructions are vague. You will learn a lot by doing assignments and final project!! Lots of effort if you want A!

Toby is a really reasonable, calm, humble and knowledgeable professor. Most of reviews giving him lower grade were written at the beginning of semester and I don't think it's fair to judge him that quickly. I didn't go to his lectures that often at the end of the course, but his reading materials cover enough for me to survive through the course.
The assignment is definitely not about what you have learned in class. I have never failed any assignments in any courses but this.
I don't even know how to describe what this class was
Imagine your worst nightmarish version of a careless bad prof and you've got Toby.

Spends his classes chatting as if it was some discord chat and has no organized presentations or class material to teach like one would expect. Beyond that he leaves everything to clueless unsupervised TAs where it is very chaotic, and you can have your grades tanked simply because they don't know how to mark or test your assignment files.
Does not care at all about actually teaching. Very chaotic class. Worst experience of my live
Run, just run for your own good. Take whatever class you need to take in another semester, even if it means waiting a couple semesters. Its for your own good

If you are looking to question your sanity whenever you spend countless hours trying to understand the assignments, wanna spend countless hours self learning the entirety of C++ because the class material is absolutely useless, and wanna risk getting an F & possibly ruin your education an curse the day you decided to enroll to SFU, then this is it

I'm not sure about his teaching in person, but online was an absolute bore. Assignment requirements are hardly clear and frequently misses things that should be on there, which makes you lose a few unnecessary marks. Despite that, super easy course if you pay attention and double-check everything.
The most disrespectful professor I've ever had.

Prof Donaldson was such an amazing prof for 125. His lectures were always really clear and he'd explain concepts from the ground up which is nice because we started learning c. We didn't have any midterms or finals, just a bunch of module quizzes which were pretty easy and the questions were word for word out of the textbook. Overall a great guy!

Lectures are well organized so if you follow them and read the notes, you'll do fine on the quizzes. He delegates the marking of assignments and the final pair project to the TAs you're assigned so he will not answer any questions about marking. But he's willing to answer any other questions for hours after lecture which is great for online classes

Toby's notes were usually quite helpful for both the Module Quizzes and the Assignments. Unfortunately, I found Toby's lectures to be quite dry. He would sometimes just read off his notes or breeze through a code without much explanation. He also made us read 12 chapters in the first 2 weeks. Not the worst prof, but definitely not the best either.

The course is unfortunately too dense (C/C++). However, Tony's lectures are amazing at explaining the topics (if you listen closely he gives great insights). Design of the quizzes were harsh (30 seconds per MC max) and if he designed the assignments, one was explained very poorly and not suitable for CMPT125. It took 24+ hrs to do well for most.
Worst Prof ever. A lot of work to do and very strict. Since is coding course, you might get plagiarism under his rule. Even its all by coincident.
he's good

we had to read about half the textbook in the first two weeks and then we never needed the textbook again. his assignments are worded in a confusing manner and his notes were more helpful than his lectures.

Toby is the definition of a low effort prof, who spends most of his time rambling about his opinions on non-technical topics. For an upper-division course, he didn't share his area of expertise/research into the lecture much. Best of all, for ML section he just showed us three 30 mins youtube videos in class.
Great prof, fun to talk to!

Toby's CMPT310 wasn't much technical. The final exam was a memory test with no problem solving questions. The midterm was easy. He just changed a few words from a sample. Assignments were not easy, but marking was generous. Overall, the course is a giveaway.
Best cmpt prof ever. He provides a lot of excellent examples during lectures and provide everything you know on the course website. Exams are very fair and everything is based on his course website.
383 was an interesting class that teaches some more obscure languages but still manages to improve your overall skill in programming. Toby teaches the course well.
Great Proff
Very nice and approachable prof but he doesn't know his material. Self study.
Very nice prof, will take his course again. The assignments are not easy but really help you to understand. Notes are online and everything are base on the notes.

IMO the best prof I've had at SFU. I've taken 135 and now 383 with him and in each of those classes I've actually learned something useful. In 383 you get really into functional programming and the languages you have to learn really teaches you to think in a different way. Very fair assignments and exams. Take this course with him.

His lectures were interesting, and his assignments were well related to the material that he taught. His midterm and final were fair, completely based on the notes for his class. Didn't use the textbook much, just read his notes on his website. If you had to take this class, take it with him!

Excellent Prof.  His online notes are awesome!  Just study those thoroughly.  His assignments are super fun.  They are like puzzles and are about the right difficulty.  Highly recommend this prof for CMPT 383!!

Great & helpful prof! Very glad to have taken 383 with him, he couldn't have explained concepts better. His midterm/final were extremely fair, if you studied you did fine - generally he will give outlines, follow them! Assignments/projects sometimes tedious but for the most part very manageable. Great course overall! Definitely recommend.
The best CMPT166 teacher ever!!!
The best pro I have ever seen in my life!!! High recommended!!!!

Great prof, doesn't teach with slides but rather through example-I find this better for programming courses as you can follow along easier. Despite what was previously said, my friends and I found him to be quite funny. Final wasn't too bad, practice the problem sets given!
Really takes the time to explain things in detail. And, instead of simply reading slides off a powerpoint, he actually engages himself into doing some examples in class.
Odd personality, very intelligent concerning his subject. Tends to have low expectations of students concerning their abilities to provide quality work.
No Comments

His lectures are ok, they are all online. But he is a little wierd in personality. He makes jokes in class that nobody laughts. I have yet to take his exams but from the looks of the Sample exams they look ok. Point: read the notes online before going to class

Great prof! Very helpful and he doesn't make you feel stupid when you ask him a question. Midterm was veryy fair and easy, it was so much easier than i thought it was going to be. Final was very fair if you studied and know your stuff.

At least the tests are scaled and somewhat easier than the terrible textbook (why easiness is 2). Otherwise, everyone would be spending WAY too much time (if not a lot already) on a course that is too hard since both the text and the prof are VERY demanding. *Sigh* Visit the TA often plz!
Very bad, not clear at all. Does not help with anything, go to another proffs lectures.

omg! he expects us to get 90+% for the hwk, and the first Q is correcting midterm 2, out of 1 or nothing if totally correct! I only expected him to be at least 60% good, but now he's not even going to pass :P

Clarity is hindered by his long, convoluted, impossible to follow proofs. Doesn't share knowledge about hwk pbms. Slightly better than the terrible txtbook that blabs all page. Txtbook hwk is difficult. Always see the TA for help or you will be farrrr behind. Tests are also difficult.
 
 Have tons of scrap paper ready to clarify MACM concepts.
